title: Israel-Hamas war deepens divide between Middle East and West
summary: From Lebanon to Jordan and Egypt, criticism is mounting against American and European leaders and media, who are accused of 'dehumanizing the Palestinians.'

title: Israel agrees to 4-hour 'humanitarian pauses' in Gaza, says White House
summary: The daily 'pauses', which will each last 4 hours and be announced 3 hours in advance, were asked for by President Joe Biden in a call with Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: EU strikes deal on key biodiversity bill
summary: The law will force EU countries to put in place measures to restore at least 20 % of the EU's land and 20 % of the EU's seas by 2030. Environmental groups welcomed the agreement while also pointing to watered-down elements.

title: Portugal's president calls election after corruption scandal
summary: Portuguese President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa said Thursday that he was dissolving the nation’s parliament and calling an early election. The announcement comes two days after Prime Minister Antonio Costa resigned over a corruption investigation.

title: 'The spectacular recovery of the US economy and job shortages have reawakened the ardor for demands among workers'
summary: In Hollywood, the actors’ strike came to an end on Wednesday, November 8, after one 118 days on the picket line. With an efficiency not seen in decades, social conflicts are multiplying in the country.

title: Frank Borman, the astronaut who led humanity's first mission around the Moon, dead at 95
summary: The NASA astronaut who led the 1968 Apollo 8 mission, the first human spaceflight to reach the Moon, passed away on November 7, the US space agency said Thursday. He became one of the first three humans to see and photograph the far side of the satellite.

title: French MPs release uncompromising report on French Africa policy
summary: The report proposes diplomatic, aid, and visa policies to help rebuild relations between France and its former colonies.

title: Spanish prime minister offers Catalan separatists amnesty to form majority
summary: Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has cut a controversial deal with Catalan separatist parties, accepting demands of amnesty for those being pursued following a 2017 failed secession attempt.

title: France accuses Russia of 'online interference' over Star of David graffiti in Paris
summary: Paris prosecutors have opened an investigation into 'some 60' Stars of David daubed on buildings in the French capital, seen as threatening Jews. Russia has denied accusations that it was behind the painting of the Stars.

title: US Democratic Senator Joe Manchin won't seek reelection, giving GOP a key pickup opportunity
summary: The Senator of West Virginia's decision to retire severely hampers Democratic hopes of holding on to the coal country seat and marks the end of an era for West Virginia, which voted reliably blue for decades before flipping red.

title: Top French court overturns ban on radical climate activist group
summary: The Council of State ruled that 'no incitement to violence against people could be blamed on' the activist group Les Soulèvements de la Terre in the case of a March 25 climate protest that saw violent clashes.

title: French politicians ask: Can you march against anti-Semitism alongside the far right?
summary: The leaders of France's Parliament called for Sunday's demonstration, but said they won't march alongside Marine Le Pen's Rassemblement National. The radical left refuses to participate.

title: French military aid to Ukraine estimated at €3.2 billion
summary: In response to criticism that Paris is not doing enough to help Kyiv, a parliamentary report details the cost of arms delivered and military training provided.

title: US Fed could hike rates again if 'appropriate'
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell said on Thursday that the institution was prepared to raise interest rates further if it is needed to bring down inflation to 2%.

title: Germany unveils huge electricity price support package for industry
summary: Announcing the deal, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz said the costs would be worth up to €12 billion in the next year alone.

title: Football: 17-year-old wonderkid Zaïre-Emery called up to France national team
summary: Paris Saint-Germain's academy product Warren Zaïre-Emery was called up for France'es matches in November after impressing on the big stage, in Ligue 1 and the Champions League.

title: Gazan hospitals at the heart of Israel-Hamas war
summary: Since October 7, healthcare workers in the Palestinian enclave have been performing in extreme conditions. Israel claims the hospitals, which house thousands of refugees, are being used as cover for Hamas's military operations.

title: Culture Minister Rima Abdul Malak: '36% women at Paris Photo is still not enough'
summary: On the occasion of the annual photography fair, Abdul Malak spoke in an interview about her work on behalf of women photographers and the French scene.

title: Georgians in Tbilisi celebrate rapprochement with EU: 'It's a historic opportunity.'
summary: On Wednesday, the European Commission gave the country a conditional green light to become an official candidate for membership of the European Union.

title: US approves first vaccine against chikungunya virus
summary: The vaccine, which will be marketed under the name Ixchiq, was approved for people 18 and over who are at increased risk of exposure, the Food and Drug Administration said Thursday. The US drug regulator's decision is expected to speed the vaccine's rollout in countries where the virus is most prevalent.

title: Mourad Merzouki sets the Musée d'Orsay dancing
summary: As part of the Cultural Olympiad, the choreographer takes to the exhibition spaces on November 11 and 12, with extracts from shows and walkabouts.

title: 'Europe's space project has overcome its contradictions and rivalries by reinventing itself at a key moment in its history'
summary: At the close of the European Space Summit in Seville on November 6 and 7, the launcher crisis remains acute. But the Europeans have mapped out the technological and industrial future of Europe's space project with ambitious views on climate and the environment, writes Philippe Baptiste, president of the Centre National d'Etudes Spatiales, in an op-ed for 'Le Monde.'

title: Gazan workers wait in Jericho: 'Here, we die a hundred times a day, when we see what's happening back home'
summary: Many Gazan workers who lost their Israeli work permits after Hamas's attack on October 7 have taken refuge in the West Bank. For the past month, they have been desperate for news from their families caught up in the bombing.

title: UK's Scotland Yard objects to government's ban on pro-Palestinian demonstration
summary: While Home Secretary Suella Braverman described the demonstrations supporting Gaza as 'hate marches,' London's Metropolitan Police said it had no legal grounds to ban the rally.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Macron calls for Gaza 'humanitarian pause' and 'preparation of a ceasefire'
summary: At a humanitarian aid conference he is hosting at the Elysée Palace, French President Emmanuel Macron also announced France would increase its aid to Palestinians from €20 million to 100 million.

title: How the Israeli army launched its ground operation in Gaza
summary: Ten days after announcing the start of its ground operation, the Israeli army declared that it had cut the Gaza Strip in two and encircled Gaza City.

title: Germans commemorate Kristallnacht terror as antisemitism is on the rise
summary: 'Any form of antisemitism poisons our society. We do not tolerate it,' said Chanchellor Olaf Scholz, speaking at a ceremony on Thursday at a Berlin synagogue that was attacked with firebombs.

title: Northern Myanmar fighting displaces almost 50,000 civilians
summary: This displacement occurred after an alliance of ethnic armed groups launched an offensive against the military two weeks ago, the UN said on Friday.

title: Macron faces dilemma over role in march against anti-Semitism
summary: It is still unclear whether the French president will attend the Paris march on Sunday. The only near-certainty is that he will be speaking on the subject in the next few days.

title: NGOs express disappointment after first humanitarian conference for Gaza
summary: President Emmanuel Macron welcomed the €1 billion in humanitarian funding pledges, and called to 'work towards a ceasefire.' But NGOs decried the lack of a consensus on an interruption in the fightint.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Gaza to get minimal 'humanitarian pauses'
summary: Since Wednesday, almost 50,000 people have been fleeing from the north to the south of the enclave.

title: Paris tests dismantling of iconic bookstalls ahead of 2024 Olympics ceremony
summary: On Friday, four secondhand bookstalls on the banks of the Seine will be dismantled and reassembled to test whether they can be moved in July 2024, before the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games on the Seine.

title: At Paris Photo, the  images move seamlessly from the real to the virtual
summary: For the first time, the fair has created a 'digital sector,' where artists  explore new technologies and the ways in which they have changed our lives.

title: Australia announces plan to help Tuvalu residents escape rising seas and storms of climate change
summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced on Friday a 'groundbreaking' agreement that will initially allow up to 280 Tuvaluans to come to Australia each year.

title: 'Phobos' ransomware: Two Russians arrested following a dozen attacks in France
summary: The couple, arrested in Italy, is suspected of working with this group since at least 2020. Little known, Phobos has nonetheless affected 200 recorded victims throughout France.

title: Biden and Xi to meet next week to 'stabilize' relations
summary: According to US officials, the two leaders are due to meet on Wednesday, around the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in San Francisco, to avoid a flare-up of conflict over Taiwan, surveillance or the wars in Ukraine and Gaza.

title: Prince Harry wins in latest round of UK media litigation
summary: The case for 'unlawful information gathering,' brought against British tabloid publishers by the former royal and others, was ruled 'a worthwhile claim', and could go to trial.
